title: Acceleration vs. Remediation: What Works for My Students

extracted_fields.results_summary: This article discusses the benefits of acceleration over remediation for struggling students, drawing on research and practitioner experience. The population includes K-12 students, particularly those in elementary and middle grades who are academically behind. The study design is qualitative, synthesizing existing research and anecdotal evidence from educators. Key outcomes include increased student confidence, participation, and self-efficacy when acceleration strategies are used. The main finding direction is positive, suggesting that acceleration helps struggling students engage more effectively with grade-level content and improves their academic self-concept.

title: Delayed Versus Immediate Feedback in an Independent Study High School Setting

extracted_fields.results_summary: This study examined the effects of delayed versus immediate feedback on high school students in an independent study setting at Brigham Young University. The research compared different feedback timing conditions (immediate vs. delayed) and feedback types (verification, elaboration, multiple-try) on student learning outcomes. The study employed a quasi-experimental design with high school students enrolled in independent study courses. Results indicated mixed findings regarding the effectiveness of immediate versus delayed feedback, with outcomes varying based on the type of feedback content provided and how students utilized the feedback information.

title: The Effects of Artificial Intelligence on Student Learning Outcomes in Secondary Mathematics Education

extracted_fields.results_summary: This study examined the effects of immediate versus deferred feedback during formative assessments in a 9th grade physical science course. The intervention compared different feedback timing approaches to understand their impact on student learning outcomes. The study focused on secondary education students in a physical science context. The research investigated feedback psychology and educational measurement practices. Due to limited extractable content from the provided metadata, specific outcome directions and effect sizes cannot be determined.

title: Comparing the Effects of Choice and Performance Feedback on the Writing Fluency Outcomes of Elementary Students

extracted_fields.results_summary: This study compared the effects of choice and performance feedback interventions on writing fluency outcomes among elementary students. The quasi-experimental design examined how providing students with choices in writing topics versus providing performance feedback affected their writing fluency. The study population consisted of elementary school students engaged in writing tasks. Results indicated mixed effects, with some students benefiting more from choice conditions while others showed greater improvement with performance feedback. The findings suggest that both interventions can support writing fluency development, but their effectiveness may vary based on individual student characteristics.
extracted_fields.measure: Writing fluency measures (words written, correct writing sequences)

title: The Impact of a Peer-Tutoring Model on the Academic Performance of Secondary Students

extracted_fields.results_summary: This study examined the impact of a peer-tutoring model on the academic performance of secondary students. The intervention involved structured peer tutoring where students worked together to improve academic outcomes. Using a quasi-experimental design, the study compared students who participated in peer tutoring with those who did not. Results indicated that students in the peer-tutoring condition demonstrated improved academic performance, particularly in literacy-related outcomes. The findings suggest that peer tutoring can be an effective instructional strategy for secondary education.

title: Formative assessment: Comparing immediate and delayed feedback

extracted_fields.results_summary: This study compared immediate versus delayed feedback in formative assessment for undergraduate students in a mathematics or quantitative reasoning context. The study employed a randomized control trial design to examine how timing of feedback affects learning outcomes. Key outcomes measured included test scores or assignment performance related to mathematical problem-solving. The main finding indicated mixed results, with neither immediate nor delayed feedback showing a consistently superior effect across all conditions.

title: Formative assessment: Comparing immediate and delayed feedback

extracted_fields.results_summary: This study compared immediate versus delayed feedback in formative assessment for undergraduate students in a mathematics or statistics course. Using a randomized control trial design, students were assigned to receive either immediate feedback after each quiz question or delayed feedback after completing the entire quiz. The primary outcome measured was quiz performance and learning gains. Results showed mixed effects, with immediate feedback benefiting some types of questions while delayed feedback was more effective for others, suggesting that optimal feedback timing may depend on question complexity and learning context.

title: AI-POWERED EDUCATIONAL TOOLS AND THEIR EFFECT ON STUDENT MOTIVATION IN ONLINE LEARNING ENVIRONMENTS: A PRELIMINARY STUDY

extracted_fields.results_summary: This preliminary study examined the effect of an AI Essay Review Tool on student motivation in online learning environments, using Self-Determination Theory as a framework. Participants included students from an Education Seminar and AP Government course who completed the Autonomy and Competence in Technology Adoption (ACTA) questionnaire. The study measured motivation scores, perceived competence scores, and calculated the Relative Autonomy Index (RAI) to assess autonomous versus controlled motivation. Findings varied by course context, with different patterns observed between the Education Seminar and AP Government groups. The study acknowledges limitations and represents a preliminary investigation into AI-powered feedback tools' impact on student motivation.
extracted_fields.measure: Relative Autonomy Index (RAI), Motivation Scores, Perceived Competence Scores via ACTA Questionnaire

title: An Investigation of the Impact of Integrated Learning System Use on Mathematics Achievement of Elementary Students

extracted_fields.results_summary: This study investigated the impact of Integrated Learning System (ILS) use on mathematics achievement among elementary students in Greeneville City schools. The research examined student achievement outcomes using standardized assessments and analyzed time spent using the MCS (Mathematics Courseware System) and MI courseware. The study employed a quasi-experimental design to compare mathematics composite gains across student cohorts. Key research questions addressed the relationship between ILS usage patterns and mathematics achievement outcomes. Due to the corrupted nature of the extracted text, specific effect sizes and detailed findings cannot be determined from the available content.

title: Effectiveness of Technology-Integrated Instruction on High School Students' Mathematic Achievement Scores

extracted_fields.results_summary: This study examined the effectiveness of technology-integrated instruction on high school students' mathematics achievement scores. The intervention involved integrating technology into mathematics instruction for high school students. Using a quasi-experimental design, the study compared outcomes between students receiving technology-integrated instruction and those receiving traditional instruction. The key outcome measured was mathematics achievement scores. The findings indicated a positive effect of technology-integrated instruction on students' mathematical achievement.

title: Inquiry Based Mathematics Instruction Versus Traditional Mathematics Instruction: The Effect on Student Understanding and Comprehension in an Eighth Grade Pre-Algebra Classroom

The primary outcome measured was mathematical understanding and comprehension. title: A Systematic Literature Review Of Online Learning And Mathematics Achievement Among Students With Disabilities, English Language Learners, And Impoverished Students

extracted_fields.results_summary: This systematic literature review examined the effects of online learning on mathematics achievement among students with disabilities, English language learners, and impoverished students. The study synthesized existing research across multiple studies to evaluate the effectiveness of online learning interventions for these vulnerable populations. The review employed systematic methodology to identify and analyze relevant studies examining mathematics outcomes. Findings indicated mixed results regarding the effectiveness of online learning for mathematics achievement among these student populations, with variability based on implementation factors and student characteristics. The review highlighted the need for more targeted research on online learning effectiveness for underserved student groups.
extracted_fields.student_socioeconomic_makeup: low-income students included as target population
